questions.text: A patient is to be operated on for a Total Knee Replacement under popliteal sciatic block with continuous neural catheter. Three hours into the surgery, after catheter top-up, the patient starts getting perioral numbness, facial twitches, bradycardia, and has a seizure. What drug should the anesthetist administer in this situation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 20% Intralipid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to memorize is that 20% Intralipid is the treatment for Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST) , which presents with symptoms such as seizures, bradycardia, and neurological symptoms following local anesthetic use.
  • ➤ 20% Intralipid
  • ➤ Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST)

questions.text: A child is posted for a bone marrow aspiration biopsy under sedation. His mother gives him just a sip of water as he is crying uncontrollably half an hour before the procedure due to thirst. In how much time can the child be taken for the procedure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 hrs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For clear liquids like water, the recommended fasting time before sedation or anesthesia is 2 hours.

questions.text: An 80-year-old male, posted for a left lower lobectomy, develops sudden hypotension intra-operatively along with the following ECG changes. What should be the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cardioversion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of hemodynamically unstable atrial fibrillation , the next step is synchronized cardioversion to restore normal heart rhythm and stabilize the patient's condition.
  • ➤ hemodynamically unstable atrial fibrillation
  • ➤ synchronized cardioversion

questions.text: A medical student is posted for her final year medicine exam. In the table viva, she is given this ECG and asked for a diagnosis. What does the ECG show?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) First-degree heart block

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ First-degree heart block is diagnosed when the PR interval is prolonged (greater than 0.20 seconds) but remains constant with no dropped beats.
  • ➤ First-degree heart block
  • ➤ PR interval is prolonged
  • ➤ constant

questions.text: A 10-year-old is undergoing posterior fossa surgery in a sitting position. He has sudden hypotension and a fall in end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2). What is the next step to be taken?

options.label: D
options.text: Continue surgery waiting for hemodynamics to stabilize

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Insert Central venous catheter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of venous air embolism (VAE) during surgery, particularly in the sitting position, immediate insertion of a central venous catheter to aspirate the air is a critical next step in management.
  • ➤ venous air embolism (VAE)
  • ➤ central venous catheter

questions.text: A Total hip replacement case of 4 hours duration is preferred to be done with what type of anesthesia ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For longer surgeries, like a Total Hip Replacement lasting around 4 hours, a Combined Spinal-Epidural (CSE) anesthesia is ideal, providing both rapid onset anesthesia and prolonged effect through continuous epidural top-ups.
  • ➤ Total Hip Replacement
  • ➤ Combined Spinal-Epidural (CSE)

questions.text: Most commonly used nerve for nerve monitoring in anesthesia is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ulnar

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ulnar nerve is the most commonly monitored nerve for assessing neuromuscular blockade using the Train-of-Four (TOF) monitor in anesthesia.
  • ➤ ulnar nerve
  • ➤ Train-of-Four (TOF) monitor

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is posted for tonsillectomy. The patient is extubated in a light plane of anesthesia. Suddenly, he starts desaturating and there is absent air entry bilaterally. What is the drug of choice in this situation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Scoline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of laryngospasm following extubation, particularly in a light plane of anesthesia , the preferred treatment is Succinylcholine (Scoline) , a fast-acting muscle relaxant, to break the spasm and restore airflow.
  • ➤ laryngospasm
  • ➤ light plane of anesthesia
  • ➤ Succinylcholine (Scoline)

questions.text: Once an advanced airway is in place, what is the recommended rate of respirations to be given?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 10 breaths / min

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When an advanced airway is in place during CPR , the recommended ventilation rate is 10 breaths per minute , or one breath every 6 seconds, to ensure proper oxygenation without causing harm from hyperventilation.
  • ➤ advanced airway
  • ➤ CPR
  • ➤ 10 breaths per minute

questions.text: In which of these conditions is rapid sequence spinal anesthesia most recommended?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rapid Sequence Spinal Anesthesia is most commonly recommended in emergency cesarean sections (LSCS) where time is critical, and the baby needs to be delivered quickly to prevent complications such as fetal distress.
  • ➤ Rapid Sequence Spinal Anesthesia
  • ➤ emergency cesarean sections (LSCS)

questions.text: What is the ratio in which chest compressions to respirations should be given in the newborn?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3:1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In newborn resuscitation , the chest compression to respiration ratio is 3:1 . This ensures proper balance between providing oxygen and maintaining circulation during resuscitation efforts.
  • ➤ newborn resuscitation
  • ➤ 3:1

questions.text: A 50-year-old is admitted for subarachnoid hemorrhage. The plan is to insert a coil at the level of the ruptured aneurysm. Which of these positions helps in reducing the ICP during the procedure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reverse Trendelenburg position

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with subarachnoid hemorrhage , placing the patient in the Reverse Trendelenburg position (head elevated) is effective in reducing intracranial pressure (ICP) by facilitating venous drainage from the brain.
  • ➤ subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • ➤ Reverse Trendelenburg position
  • ➤ intracranial pressure (ICP)

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with septic shock is admitted to the ICU for management. His treatment includes high doses of corticosteroids and vasopressors to maintain blood pressure. Despite initial improvement, his condition deteriorates with worsening hypotension and electrolyte imbalance. Further investigation reveals an inadequate cortisol response. He requires emergency surgery for an abdominal source of infection. Which anesthetic agent should be avoided?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Etomidate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Etomidate should be avoided in patients with adrenal insufficiency or conditions like septic shock where adequate cortisol levels are crucial, as it can inhibit cortisol synthesis by blocking 11-beta hydroxylase , leading to further deterioration in hemodynamic stability.
  • ➤ Etomidate
  • ➤ adrenal insufficiency
  • ➤ septic shock
  • ➤ 11-beta hydroxylase

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a weight of 150 kg undergoes bariatric surgery. On post-operative day 1, he becomes acutely breathless and has to be intubated and put on mechanical ventilation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pulmonary embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In post-surgical patients, especially those with obesity, pulmonary embolism is a key consideration when acute breathlessness occurs, particularly early in the post-operative period. DVT can develop due to immobility and other risk factors, with the potential for embolism leading to respiratory compromise.
  • ➤ pulmonary embolism
  • ➤ DVT

questions.text: During a CPCR situation, the nurse is unable to find IV access. The doctor in charge directs her to give drugs diluted in saline through the endotracheal tube (ETT). Which of these life-saving drugs can be given through ETT?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In emergency situations where IV access is unavailable during CPR, Atropine, Adrenaline (Epinephrine), and Lignocaine can all be administered via the endotracheal tube (ETT) , making the correct answer D. All of the above .
  • ➤ Atropine, Adrenaline (Epinephrine), and Lignocaine
  • ➤ endotracheal tube (ETT)
  • ➤ D. All of the above

questions.text: Identify the test shown in the image.

options.label: D
options.text: Detection of factor V leiden mutation

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thromboelastogram

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The test shown in the image is a Thromboelastogram (TEG) , which provides a comprehensive assessment of clot formation, stability, and fibrinolysis, helping guide clinical decisions related to coagulopathy management.
  • ➤ Thromboelastogram (TEG)

questions.text: Which of these is a complication of a procedure carried out by the instrument shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) PDPH (Post-dural puncture headache)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary complication of an epidural procedure with a Tuohy needle is accidental dural puncture , leading to Post-Dural Puncture Headache (PDPH) , which can occur if the dura is breached during the procedure.
  • ➤ epidural procedure
  • ➤ Tuohy needle
  • ➤ dural puncture
  • ➤ Post-Dural Puncture Headache (PDPH)

questions.text: All are effects of Ketamine except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypotension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ketamine typically causes tachycardia , analgesia , and amnesia , but hypotension is not a usual effect. Instead, ketamine often causes increased blood pressure and is preferred in hemodynamically unstable patients.
  • ➤ tachycardia
  • ➤ analgesia
  • ➤ amnesia
  • ➤ hypotension
  • ➤ increased blood pressure

questions.text: the instrument in the image.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pulmonary artery catheter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The image shows a Pulmonary Artery Catheter (Swan-Ganz) , which is used to measure pulmonary and cardiac pressures in critically ill patients.
  • ➤ Pulmonary Artery Catheter (Swan-Ganz)

questions.text: During a surgery for fixation of a fracture neck of femur under spinal anesthesia, the patient starts becoming breathless with hypotension during reaming of the femur. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fat embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fat embolism syndrome (FES) is the most likely cause of acute respiratory distress and hypotension during or after orthopedic surgery involving long bones, such as femur reaming.
  • ➤ Fat embolism syndrome (FES)

questions.text: After which scientist is this maneuver named?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sellick

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The maneuver shown is called the Sellick maneuver or cricoid pressure , used to prevent aspiration during rapid sequence intubation by applying pressure on the cricoid cartilage.
  • ➤ Sellick maneuver
  • ➤ cricoid pressure

questions.text: A patient undergoing hernia surgery under spinal anesthesia starts becoming agitated, and the anesthetist administers quetiapine to calm him down. After 5 minutes, he suddenly shows an increase in EtCO2 from 40 mm Hg to 100 mm Hg along with a rise in his core body temperature to 40 degrees Celsius. What do you think is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) can be triggered by neuroleptic drugs like quetiapine, and it presents with hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, and elevated EtCO2. Although it shares features with malignant hyperthermia, the triggering agent distinguishes the two conditions.
  • ➤ Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS)
  • ➤ neuroleptic drugs

questions.text: A 3 day old child has to be given urgent dextrose iv due to severe hypoglycemia. The senior resident asks the intern to put smallest size iv for the patient. Which would you choose ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For neonates requiring IV access, such as in this case of urgent dextrose administration due to hypoglycemia, the 24G (Purple) cannula is the smallest size and best suited for this purpose.
  • ➤ 24G (Purple) cannula

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of chronic smoking is scheduled to undergo thoracotomy for resection of a pulmonary nodule. The surgical team plans a procedure that requires complete collapse of the left lung to provide better access to the operative field and to minimize the movement of the lung during resection. Which of the following is the most appropriate tube to be used in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For procedures requiring one-lung ventilation (such as a thoracotomy), a Double Lumen Tube (DLT) is the preferred choice, as it allows for effective lung isolation and collapse of one lung while maintaining ventilation in the other.
  • ➤ one-lung ventilation
  • ➤ Double Lumen Tube (DLT)

questions.text: A 4 year old child is intubated by a pediatric resident by direct laryngoscopy. The professor asks him to check the depth of insertion of the tube by the formula given . Which formula should the resident be referring to ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Age/2 + 12

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct formula for estimating the depth of ETT insertion in pediatric patients is Age/2 + 12 , which ensures proper placement of the tube to ventilate both lungs effectively. For a 4-year-old, this would result in a depth of 14 cm at the incisors.
  • ➤ depth of ETT insertion in pediatric patients
  • ➤ Age/2 + 12
  • ➤ 14 cm

questions.text: You have intubated a 4-year-old child for surgery. This is the chest X-ray taken after intubation. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reposition tube

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of endobronchial intubation , as shown in the chest X-ray, the solution is to reposition the tube by withdrawing it slightly to ensure both lungs are ventilated properly.
  • ➤ endobronchial intubation
  • ➤ reposition the tube

questions.text: A patient in the EMS is having a seizure. There is no bite block available. Which of the following can be used instead to prevent a tongue bite?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the absence of a bite block, a Guedel's Oropharyngeal Airway (OPA) can be safely used to prevent tongue biting in patients experiencing seizures, while also maintaining a patent airway.
  • ➤ Guedel's Oropharyngeal Airway (OPA)

questions.text: Assertion: Atracurium can be safely given in renal failure patients. Reason: Atracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination.

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.correct_answer: A. Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination , making it a safe muscle relaxant for patients with renal failure as its metabolism does not depend on kidney function.
  • ➤ Atracurium
  • ➤ Hofmann elimination
  • ➤ renal failure

questions.text: an obstetric cardiac arrest, what is the best location for IV access out of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) External Jugular Vein (EJV)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During obstetric cardiac arrest , the External Jugular Vein (EJV) is the best site for IV access due to its rapid accessibility and proximity to the central circulation.
  • ➤ obstetric cardiac arrest
  • ➤ External Jugular Vein (EJV)

questions.text: After activating the emergency response system, what is the next step?

options.label: A
options.text: Start chest compressions at a ratio of 30: 2

options.label: B
options.text: Check for a pulse for 10 seconds

options.label: C
options.text: Start chest compressions at a ratio of 15: 2

options.label: D
options.text: Check for a pulse for 3 to 5 seconds

questions.correct_answer: B. Check for a pulse for 10 seconds
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Check for a pulse for 10 seconds

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ After activating the emergency response system, you should check for a pulse for no more than 10 seconds before starting CPR if the pulse is absent.
  • ➤ check for a pulse for no more than 10 seconds

questions.text: Identify the LMA in the picture:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Proseal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ProSeal LMA is characterized by its dual tubes—one for the airway and one for gastric drainage—making it ideal for procedures with a risk of aspiration, such as laparoscopic surgeries.
  • ➤ ProSeal LMA

questions.text: All are true regarding the quality of CPR except?

options.label: A
options.text: Depth of Compression should be at least 5 cm

options.label: B
options.text: Complete Chest Recoil is allowed in between Compressions

options.label: C
options.text: If PET CO2 < 20 mm Hg, Improve the Quality of CPR

options.label: D
options.text: Chest Compression: Ventilation Ratio should be 30:2

questions.correct_answer: C. If PET CO2 < 20 mm Hg, Improve the Quality of CPR
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) If PETCO₂ < 20 mm Hg, Improve the Quality of CPR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A PETCO₂ value of less than 10 mm Hg indicates poor quality chest compressions during CPR, and compressions need to be improved.
  • ➤ PETCO₂ value of less than 10 mm Hg

questions.text: A 32-year-old male undergoes dental surgery under local anesthesia with a reported history of a previous dental procedure where he received an anesthetic agent. Shortly after the procedure, he begins to experience shortness of breath, cyanosis and lightheadedness. His oxygen saturation drops to 85% despite being on 100% oxygen. Blood drawn for analysis appears chocolate-brown in color, and a co-oximetry test confirms the presence of methemoglobinemia. Which of the following local anesthetic agents is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Prilocaine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prilocaine is the local anesthetic most commonly associated with methemoglobinemia due to its metabolism to o-toluidine , which can oxidize hemoglobin, leading to decreased oxygen-carrying capacity.
  • ➤ o-toluidine

questions.text: A one year old child has an acute asthmatic attack at home .which of the following devices can be prescribed for home use for acute exacerbation for this child ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For infants and toddlers, a nebulizer is the preferred device for delivering asthma medications during an acute attack at home, as it ensures adequate delivery of the medication without requiring precise coordination.
  • ➤ nebulizer

questions.text: Ramu is on maintenance therapy for MDR-TB. He is to be operated on for an inguinal hernia repair. Which of these blood tests is of particular importance to the anesthetist?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Liver function test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Liver function tests are of particular importance for patients undergoing MDR-TB treatment , as many anti-tuberculosis drugs are hepatotoxic and can impact the metabolism of anesthetic agents.
  • ➤ Liver function tests
  • ➤ MDR-TB treatment

questions.text: A 20-year-old primigravida had an epileptic attack in the morning. She was diagnosed to have pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH) for 2 months. What kind of anesthesia should be given for her LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section)?

options.label: D
options.text: Defer surgery as she had seizure today

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) General anesthesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with PIH and a recent seizure , general anesthesia is preferred for LSCS to ensure airway control, manage the risk of further seizures, and maintain hemodynamic stability.
  • ➤ PIH
  • ➤ seizure
  • ➤ general anesthesia

questions.text: Meenu has been on oral contraceptive (OC) pills for 10 years and is scheduled for hip replacement surgery, followed by 3 months of immobilization. How should the OC pills be managed pre-operatively?
questions.correct_answer: C. Stop 4 weeks prior to surgery
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Stop 4 weeks prior to surgery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients on oral contraceptive pills who are scheduled for major surgery with prolonged immobilization, the OC pills should be stopped 4 weeks before surgery to minimize the risk of venous thromboembolism .
  • ➤ oral contraceptive pills
  • ➤ stopped 4 weeks before surgery
  • ➤ venous thromboembolism

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is brought to the emergency department with septic shock secondary to pneumonia. He requires intubation and mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The intensivist chooses etomidate for intubation. The patient's condition stabilizes, but on the following day, his blood pressure drops significantly despite adequate fluid resuscitation and antibiotic therapy. What is a potential adverse effect that could contribute to this patient's acute decline in blood pressure after stabilization?
questions.correct_answer: C. Inhibition of adrenal steroid synthesis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inhibition of adrenal steroid synthesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Etomidate inhibits adrenal steroid synthesis, particularly cortisol and aldosterone , leading to adrenal insufficiency , which can cause hypotension in critically ill patients, particularly in the setting of sepsis or septic shock. This adverse effect must be considered when using etomidate for intubation, especially in patients with septic shock.
  • ➤ Etomidate
  • ➤ cortisol
  • ➤ aldosterone
  • ➤ adrenal insufficiency
  • ➤ hypotension

questions.text: A child is to be taken for supracondylar fracture fixation. He is on formula-fed milk. After how much time can he be taken for surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 6 hrs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a child on formula-fed milk , the recommended fasting period before surgery is 6 hours to reduce the risk of aspiration during anesthesia.
  • ➤ formula-fed milk
  • ➤ 6 hours

questions.text: The Mapleson circuit of choice in adults for spontaneous ventilation is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mapleson A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For spontaneous ventilation in adults , the Mapleson A circuit is the most efficient and preferred choice.
  • ➤ spontaneous ventilation in adults
  • ➤ Mapleson A

questions.text: Which of these muscle relaxants is the safest to be given during a renal transplant surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Atracurium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atracurium is the muscle relaxant of choice in renal transplant surgery due to its unique metabolism via Hofmann elimination , which is independent of renal function, making it safer for patients with renal impairment.
  • ➤ Atracurium
  • ➤ renal transplant surgery
  • ➤ Hofmann elimination

questions.text: During a routine orthopedic surgery on a 45-year-old woman, a spinal anesthetic is administered for postoperative pain management. Shortly after administration, the patient complains of dizziness, followed by difficulty speaking and a sensation of heaviness in her chest. Her blood pressure begins to drop rapidly, and she becomes unresponsive to verbal commands. The patient's breathing becomes shallow, and oxygen saturation starts to decline. What is the most likely complication this patient is experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Total spinal anesthesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Total spinal anesthesia is a serious complication of spinal anesthesia that can lead to severe hypotension , respiratory depression , and loss of consciousness due to the anesthetic spreading to higher levels than intended, affecting both motor and autonomic functions. Immediate management with airway and circulatory support is critical.
  • ➤ Total spinal anesthesia
  • ➤ severe hypotension
  • ➤ respiratory depression
  • ➤ loss of consciousness

questions.text: A patient is given rocuronium during intubation. The anesthetist is unable to ventilate him and wants to reverse the action of rocuronium immediately. Which drug should she look for?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sugammadex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases where rapid reversal of rocuronium -induced neuromuscular blockade is required, sugammadex is the most effective and specific reversal agent.
  • ➤ rapid reversal
  • ➤ rocuronium
  • ➤ sugammadex

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is posted for an emergency laparotomy. His abdominal X-ray is shown below. Which of these agents will you avoid?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nitrous oxide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nitrous oxide should be avoided in patients with intestinal obstruction due to the risk of gas expansion in the bowel, leading to increased pressure and potential perforation.
  • ➤ Nitrous oxide
  • ➤ intestinal obstruction

questions.text: Usha is unable to intubate or insert an LMA in a patient posted for emergency laparotomy despite several attempts. There is severe bronchospasm due to airway trauma, and there is no chest rise or EtCO2 on mask ventilation. What should be the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Emergency Cricothyroidotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a can't intubate, can't oxygenate (CICO) scenario, the immediate next step is to perform an emergency cricothyroidotomy to establish a secure airway and provide oxygen to the patient, preventing severe hypoxia and potential death.
  • ➤ can't intubate, can't oxygenate
  • ➤ emergency cricothyroidotomy

questions.text: A 40-year-old male developed peak airway pressures, tachycardia, and hypertension after receiving atracurium intra-operatively. What should the anesthetist administer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Adrenaline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected anaphylaxis or severe allergic reactions due to atracurium , the immediate administration of adrenaline is critical for stabilizing the patient by addressing the airway, cardiovascular symptoms, and histamine release.
  • ➤ anaphylaxis
  • ➤ atracurium
  • ➤ adrenaline

questions.text: A patient posted for transesophageal esophagectomy is hypothyroid, hypertensive, diabetic, and on antidepressants. Which of these drugs should be discontinued on the day of surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Oral hypoglycemic drugs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients undergoing surgery who are diabetic, oral hypoglycemic agents should be discontinued on the day of surgery due to the risk of hypoglycemia from fasting. Blood glucose should be managed appropriately using alternative strategies such as insulin.
  • ➤ oral hypoglycemic agents
  • ➤ discontinued
  • ➤ hypoglycemia

questions.text: During an anesthesia viva, the consultant asks the student what inhalational agent is filled in this vaporizer.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Halothane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The vaporizer shown with a red top is designed for Halothane . Vaporizers are color-coded based on the agent they contain to prevent errors in the operating room.
  • ➤ red top
  • ➤ Halothane

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is posted for posterior fossa tumor excision surgery under general anesthesia. Which of these inhalational agents having the lowest blood gas partition coefficient can be used in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Desflurane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Desflurane has the lowest blood-gas partition coefficient among commonly used inhalational agents, making it the fastest-acting and quickest to recover from, which is ideal for surgeries where rapid control over anesthesia and quick recovery are essential.

questions.text: A patient is given 100% oxygen at the end of anesthesia after discontinuing nitrous oxide (N2O) and extubating. This practice primarily aims to prevent which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Diffusion Hypoxia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diffusion hypoxia is prevented by administering 100% oxygen after discontinuing nitrous oxide at the end of anesthesia to ensure adequate oxygenation as nitrous oxide rapidly diffuses out of the lungs.
  • ➤ Diffusion hypoxia

questions.text: All of the following are amide-linked local anesthetics except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Procaine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Procaine is an ester-linked local anesthetic, while Bupivacaine, Lidocaine, and Mepivacaine are amide-linked local anesthetics.
  • ➤ Procaine
  • ➤ Bupivacaine, Lidocaine, and Mepivacaine

questions.text: Which of the following tests is considered the most predictive for a difficult intubation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Upper lip bite test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Upper Lip Bite Test (ULBT) is the most predictive test for difficult intubation, evaluating jaw mobility and dental structure.
  • ➤ Upper Lip Bite Test (ULBT)

questions.text: In the scenario of selecting a drug for total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA), which agent is considered the optimal choice?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Propofol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Propofol is the agent of choice for total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA) due to its rapid onset, short half-life, stable anesthesia maintenance, and antiemetic effects, making it ideal for both short and long procedures.
  • ➤ Propofol
  • ➤ total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA)

questions.text: Who is commonly referred to as the "Father of Modern Anesthesia"?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) William T. G. Morton

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ William T. G. Morton is recognized as the "Father of Modern Anesthesia" for his demonstration of ether as a general anesthetic in surgery, an event that transformed the practice of medicine.
  • ➤ William T. G. Morton
  • ➤ "Father of Modern Anesthesia"

questions.text: In preparing for anesthesia, fasting guidelines are important to reduce the risk of pulmonary aspiration. Match the following preoperative fasting recommendations with their respective time frames: Clear Liquids Breast Milk Infant Formula Mysore masala dosa a. 2 hours b. 4 hours c. 6 hours d. 8 hours
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-a, 2-b, 3-c, 4-d

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Preoperative fasting recommendations vary by food and liquid type: clear liquids for 2 hours, breast milk for 4 hours, infant formula for 6 hours, and solid meals (like Mysore masala dosa) for 8 hours.
  • ➤ clear liquids for 2 hours, breast milk for 4 hours, infant formula for 6 hours, and solid meals (like Mysore masala dosa) for 8 hours.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with a post-dural puncture headache following an epidural during labor. Despite conservative management with hydration and caffeine, her symptoms persist. What is the gold standard treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Epidural blood patch

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epidural blood patch is the gold standard treatment for persistent post-dural puncture headache when conservative measures are ineffective.
  • ➤ Epidural blood patch
  • ➤ post-dural puncture headache

questions.text: Which combination of maneuvers is typically employed to maintain an open airway in an unconscious patient without suspected cervical spine injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Chin lift, neck extension, and mouth inspection

options.label: B
options.text: Tongue pull, neck brace, and mouth opening

options.label: C
options.text: Jaw push, head stabilization, and nose pinch

options.label: D
options.text: Chin lift, head tilt, and jaw thrust

questions.correct_answer: D. Chin lift, head tilt, and jaw thrust
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chin lift, head tilt, and jaw thrust

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In an unconscious patient without suspected cervical spine injury, the chin lift, head tilt, and jaw thrust maneuvers are used to maintain an open airway.
  • ➤ chin lift, head tilt, and jaw thrust

questions.text: Regarding non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, which of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.text: They cause muscle fasciculations upon administration

options.label: B
options.text: They are metabolized by plasma cholinesterase

options.label: C
options.text: They exhibit a shorter duration of action compared to depolarizing muscle relaxants

options.label: D
options.text: They can reverse the effects of neuromuscular blockade using neostigmine

questions.correct_answer: D. They can reverse the effects of neuromuscular blockade using neostigmine
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) They can reverse the effects of neuromuscular blockade using neostigmine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants can be reversed by neostigmine , a cholinesterase inhibitor, which increases acetylcholine availability at the neuromuscular junction to overcome the blockade.
  • ➤ non-depolarizing muscle relaxants
  • ➤ neostigmine

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of day care surgery for patients?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased access to specialized medical care

options.label: C
options.text: Longer hospital stays for adequate recovery

questions.correct_answer: A. Reduced risk of postoperative complications
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reduced risk of postoperative complications

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The main advantage of day care surgery is that it minimizes hospital stay and reduces the risk of postoperative complications , including hospital-acquired infections, while promoting quicker recovery in a home setting.
  • ➤ day care surgery
  • ➤ postoperative complications

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with Type II Diabetes is posted for surgery. His HbA1c is 8 gm % and he has no other complaints. What is his ASA-physical status classification?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ASA-PS III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A patient with poorly controlled Type II Diabetes (HbA1c of 8 gm%) falls under the ASA-PS III classification due to the presence of severe systemic disease causing functional limitations.
  • ➤ poorly controlled Type II Diabetes
  • ➤ ASA-PS III

questions.text: Identify the equipment used for intubation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Millers’ Laryngoscope

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Millers' Laryngoscope is a straight-bladed laryngoscope that is commonly used in pediatric cases and situations where the airway anatomy is challenging.
  • ➤ Millers' Laryngoscope

questions.text: In preparation for elective surgery, what is the recommended duration for discontinuing P2Y12 inhibitor to minimize the risk of bleeding complications?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 7 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients on P2Y12 inhibitors, the standard recommendation is to discontinue the drug 7 days before elective surgery to minimize bleeding risk while allowing adequate recovery of platelet function.
  • ➤ discontinue the drug 7 days before elective surgery

questions.text: Which substance is the main component of a carbon dioxide absorber used in anesthesia machines?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Calcium hydroxide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The main substance used in CO₂ absorbers in anesthesia machines is calcium hydroxide , which helps neutralize and remove CO₂ during anesthesia, ensuring safe and effective patient ventilation.Bottom of Form
  • ➤ CO₂ absorbers in anesthesia machines
  • ➤ calcium hydroxide

questions.text: What is the last structure pierced while performing lumbar puncture?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arachnoid mater

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a lumbar puncture , the arachnoid mater is the last structure pierced, giving access to the subarachnoid space , where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is found.
  • ➤ lumbar puncture
  • ➤ arachnoid mater
  • ➤ subarachnoid space

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy undergoes general anesthesia for a routine appendectomy. Shortly after the induction of anesthesia with halothane and succinylcholine, his end-tidal CO2 abruptly rises, and he develops tachycardia, hyperthermia, and muscle rigidity. Which of the following is a key intracellular ion change associated with the pathophysiology of the condition mentioned here?
questions.correct_answer: D. Increased release of calcium ions
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increased release of calcium ions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malignant hyperthermia is triggered by the massive release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in muscle cells, leading to a hypermetabolic state with muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, and tachycardia. It is a life-threatening condition associated with certain anesthetic agents like halothane and succinylcholine .
  • ➤ Malignant hyperthermia
  • ➤ release of calcium ions
  • ➤ halothane
  • ➤ succinylcholine

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient is posted for Colles fracture repair. The anesthetist wants to give a supraclavicular brachial plexus block. What instrument can she use?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The appropriate instrument for performing a supraclavicular brachial plexus block is the Peripheral Nerve Locator (Nerve Stimulator) , which aids in locating the nerve through muscle responses, ensuring accurate local anesthetic injection.
  • ➤ supraclavicular brachial plexus block
  • ➤ Peripheral Nerve Locator (Nerve Stimulator)

questions.text: What size LMA (Laryngeal Mask Airway) would you insert in a neonate of 4 kg?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Size 1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a neonate weighing 4 kg , the appropriate size of LMA is Size 1 .
  • ➤ neonate weighing 4 kg
  • ➤ Size 1

questions.text: A first-year anesthesia resident intubates a patient posted for laparoscopic hernia surgery. After 2 minutes, the consultant notices the following EtCO₂ (as seen in the image). What should be done?

options.label: D
options.text: Do a fiberoptic bronchoscopy through the ETT to detect the problem

questions.correct_answer: C. Reintubate and Reposition the ETT
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reintubate and reposition the ETT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An abrupt drop in EtCO₂ to near-zero levels after intubation indicates that the ETT is likely misplaced (e.g., esophageal intubation or dislodgement). The correct action is to reintubate and reposition the ETT to restore effective ventilation.
  • ➤ abrupt drop in EtCO₂ to near-zero levels
  • ➤ ETT is likely misplaced
  • ➤ reintubate and reposition the ETT

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is complaining of acute onset breathlessness, fever, and cough for 3 days. Her SpO₂ is 90% on room air, RR is 38 breaths per minute, HR is 102 beats per minute, and BP is 150/90 mmHg. You attach nasal prongs with 5 L/min oxygen flow. The ABG shows: pO₂: 100 mmHg pH: 7.2 pCO₂: 55 mmHg HCO₃⁻: 24 mEq/L What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Start NIV / CPAP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with respiratory failure showing signs of hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis (high pCO₂ and low pH), the next step is to provide NIV/CPAP to assist ventilation and improve gas exchange. Oxygen delivery alone (via nasal prongs or masks) will not correct the underlying ventilatory problem.
  • ➤ respiratory failure
  • ➤ hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis
  • ➤ NIV/CPAP

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes with a history of dry cough, chest pain, and palpitations. His SpO₂ on room air is 85%. He has tested positive for the novel coronavirus. Which of these devices will give the least FiO₂?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Among the options, nasal prongs deliver the least FiO₂ (around 24-40%), whereas other devices like the NIV/CPAP mask , NRBM , and HFNC can deliver much higher oxygen concentrations.
  • ➤ nasal prongs
  • ➤ least FiO₂
  • ➤ NIV/CPAP mask
  • ➤ NRBM
  • ➤ HFNC

questions.text: A patient is undergoing robotic hepatectomy. Identify the position given by the surgeon to facilitate visualization.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Reverse Trendelenburg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Reverse Trendelenburg position is used in robotic hepatectomies to improve visualization of the upper abdominal structures by allowing gravity to move the abdominal organs downward.
  • ➤ Reverse Trendelenburg position
  • ➤ robotic hepatectomies
  • ➤ upper abdominal structures

questions.text: A COVID-positive patient is admitted with breathlessness and SpO₂ of 90%. He is having severe chest pain. Identify the equipment attached to him.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) HFNC

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The equipment shown is High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) , which provides humidified, heated oxygen at flow rates high enough to deliver up to 100% FiO₂ , often used in patients with respiratory distress such as in COVID-19 pneumonia.
  • ➤ High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC)
  • ➤ up to 100% FiO₂
  • ➤ respiratory distress
  • ➤ COVID-19

questions.text: An OT technician pulls out the blue pipeline from the socket. Which gas flow will be interrupted?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nitrous oxide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medical gas pipelines in the operating room are color-coded to prevent errors:
  • ➤ Oxygen : White/Green Nitrous Oxide : Blue Air : Black Vacuum : Yellow
  • ➤ Oxygen : White/Green
  • ➤ Oxygen
  • ➤ Nitrous Oxide : Blue
  • ➤ Nitrous Oxide
  • ➤ Air : Black
  • ➤ Air
  • ➤ Vacuum : Yellow
  • ➤ Vacuum

questions.text: n an exam viva, a final MBBS student is asked what the use of this cart is. What should he answer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Airway cart

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This is an airway cart containing tools like laryngoscope blades, oropharyngeal and nasopharyngeal airways, and Magill forceps, all essential for airway management during procedures like intubation.
  • ➤ airway cart

questions.text: Inhalational agent of choice in children for induction of anesthesia is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sevoflurane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sevoflurane is the preferred inhalational agent for the induction of anesthesia in children due to its rapid onset, pleasant odor, and minimal airway irritation.
  • ➤ Sevoflurane
  • ➤ preferred inhalational agent
